natural problem: Two fair 6-sided dice are rolled.  What is the probability "doubles" are rolled (i.e., that the two dice show the same number)?
natural solution: There are 6 different ways to roll doubles which means the probability of rolling doubles is $\dfrac{6}{36} = \boxed{\dfrac{1}{6}}$.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A B :: "real set" and P :: "real set \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "A = {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6}"
and h1 : "B = {x. \<exists>y. y \<in> A \<and> x = y}"
and h2 : "\<forall>E. E \<subseteq> A \<times> B \<longrightarrow> P E = real_of_nat (card E) / 36"
shows  "P {(x, y). x = y \<and> x \<in> A \<and> y \<in> B} = 1/6"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Two fair 6-sided dice are rolled.  What is the probability "doubles" are rolled (i.e., that the two dice show the same number)? The final Answer is \dfrac{1}{6}
 ### Proof
 There are 6 different ways to roll doubles which means the probability of rolling doubles is $\dfrac{6}{36} = \boxed{\dfrac{1}{6}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes A B :: "real set" and P :: "real set \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "A = {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6}"
and h1 : "B = {x. \<exists>y. y \<in> A \<and> x = y}"
and h2 : "\<forall>E. E \<subseteq> A \<times> B \<longrightarrow> P E = real_of_nat (card E) / 36"
shows  "P {(x, y). x = y \<and> x \<in> A \<and> y \<in> B} = 1/6"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Given sets A and B where A consists of the numbers {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6} and B consists of all elements y in A such that x = y. If a function P is defined such that for any subset E of the Cartesian product of A and B, P(E) is equal to the cardinality of E divided by 36. What is the value of P for the set of all pairs (x, y) where x equals y and both x and y are in A and B? The final answer is 1/6.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A B :: "int set" and P :: "int set \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "A = {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6}"
and h1 : "B = {(x, y). x \<in> A \<and> y \<in> A \<and> x = y}"
and h2 : "P = (\<lambda> X. real (card X) / real ((card A) * (card A)))"
shows  "P B = 1 / 6"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Two fair 6-sided dice are rolled.  What is the probability "doubles" are rolled (i.e., that the two dice show the same number)? The final Answer is \dfrac{1}{6}
 ### Proof
 There are 6 different ways to roll doubles which means the probability of rolling doubles is $\dfrac{6}{36} = \boxed{\dfrac{1}{6}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes A B :: "int set" and P :: "int set \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "A = {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6}"
and h1 : "B = {(x, y). x \<in> A \<and> y \<in> A \<and> x = y}"
and h2 : "P = (\<lambda> X. real (card X) / real ((card A) * (card A)))"
shows  "P B = 1 / 6"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Suppose we have two sets A and B. Set A contains 6 unique integers {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6}. Set B is a set of all pairs (x, y) where x and y are elements of A and x equals y. If we define a function P that assigns to each set X a real number equal to the ratio of the cardinality of X to the square of the cardinality of set A, what is P(B)? The final answer is $1/6$.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A B :: "real set"
assumes h0 : "A = {1,2,3,4,5,6}"
and h1 : "B = {(a,b). a \<in> A \<and> b \<in> A \<and> a = b}"
and h2 : "prob_space A"
and h3 : "indep_vars (\<lambda>_. borel) (\<lambda>_. A) [0..<2]"
shows  "prob B = 1 / 6"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Two fair 6-sided dice are rolled.  What is the probability "doubles" are rolled (i.e., that the two dice show the same number)? The final Answer is \dfrac{1}{6}
 ### Proof
 There are 6 different ways to roll doubles which means the probability of rolling doubles is $\dfrac{6}{36} = \boxed{\dfrac{1}{6}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes A B :: "real set"
assumes h0 : "A = {1,2,3,4,5,6}"
and h1 : "B = {(a,b). a \<in> A \<and> b \<in> A \<and> a = b}"
and h2 : "prob_space A"
and h3 : "indep_vars (\<lambda>_. borel) (\<lambda>_. A) [0..<2]"
shows  "prob B = 1 / 6"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: We have a set A that contains the numbers {1,2,3,4,5,6}. We also have another set B that contains all pairs (a,b) such that both a and b are in A and a equals b. If A is a probability space and the variables are independent, what is the probability of B? The final answer is 1/6.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A B :: "int set" 
and P :: "int set \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "A = {1,2,3,4,5,6}"
and h1 : "B = {(a,a) |a. a \<in> A}"
and h2 : "P = (\<lambda> X. real (card X) / real (card A ^ 2))"
shows  "P B = 1/6"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Two fair 6-sided dice are rolled.  What is the probability "doubles" are rolled (i.e., that the two dice show the same number)? The final Answer is \dfrac{1}{6}
 ### Proof
 There are 6 different ways to roll doubles which means the probability of rolling doubles is $\dfrac{6}{36} = \boxed{\dfrac{1}{6}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes A B :: "int set" 
and P :: "int set \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "A = {1,2,3,4,5,6}"
and h1 : "B = {(a,a) |a. a \<in> A}"
and h2 : "P = (\<lambda> X. real (card X) / real (card A ^ 2))"
shows  "P B = 1/6"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: Let set A be the set of integers {1,2,3,4,5,6}. Define set B as the set of ordered pairs (a, a) where a is an element of A. Define a function P on a set X as the ratio of the cardinality of X to the square of the cardinality of A. Find the value of P(B). The final answer is 1/6.

a_4.formal problem:
definition "dice_faces = {1,2,3,4,5,6}"

definition "dice_events = {(a,b) | a b. a ∈ dice_faces & b ∈ dice_faces}"

definition "doubles = {(a,a) | a. a ∈ dice_faces}"

theorem
assumes h0 : "finite dice_events"
and h1 : "doubles ⊆ dice_events"
shows  "prob doubles dice_events = 1/6"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Two fair 6-sided dice are rolled.  What is the probability "doubles" are rolled (i.e., that the two dice show the same number)? The final Answer is \dfrac{1}{6}
 ### Proof
 There are 6 different ways to roll doubles which means the probability of rolling doubles is $\dfrac{6}{36} = \boxed{\dfrac{1}{6}}$.
 *)

definition "dice_faces = {1,2,3,4,5,6}"

definition "dice_events = {(a,b) | a b. a ∈ dice_faces & b ∈ dice_faces}"

definition "doubles = {(a,a) | a. a ∈ dice_faces}"

theorem
assumes h0 : "finite dice_events"
and h1 : "doubles ⊆ dice_events"
shows  "prob doubles dice_events = 1/6"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: In a game where two dice are rolled, each with faces numbered from 1 to 6, calculate the probability that the two dice show the same number. The final answer is $1/6$.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem 
fixes dice :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>n. n \<ge> 1 \<and> n \<le> 6 \<longrightarrow> (1/6 :: real) = dice n"
and h1 : "\<forall>n m. n \<ge> 1 \<and> n \<le> 6 \<and> m \<ge> 1 \<and> m \<le> 6 \<longrightarrow> n = m \<longrightarrow> (1/36 :: real) = dice n * dice m"
shows  "\<Sum> n \<in> {1..6}. (dice n * dice n) = (1/6 :: real)"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Two fair 6-sided dice are rolled.  What is the probability "doubles" are rolled (i.e., that the two dice show the same number)? The final Answer is \dfrac{1}{6}
 ### Proof
 There are 6 different ways to roll doubles which means the probability of rolling doubles is $\dfrac{6}{36} = \boxed{\dfrac{1}{6}}$.
 *)

theorem 
fixes dice :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>n. n \<ge> 1 \<and> n \<le> 6 \<longrightarrow> (1/6 :: real) = dice n"
and h1 : "\<forall>n m. n \<ge> 1 \<and> n \<le> 6 \<and> m \<ge> 1 \<and> m \<le> 6 \<longrightarrow> n = m \<longrightarrow> (1/36 :: real) = dice n * dice m"
shows  "\<Sum> n \<in> {1..6}. (dice n * dice n) = (1/6 :: real)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: Assume a fair six-sided die, each face of which has an equal probability of 1/6 of being rolled. If the probability of rolling two identical numbers (i.e., both dice show the same number) is 1/36, what is the sum of the squares of the probabilities of rolling each individual number (from 1 to 6)? The final answer is 1/6.

a_6.formal problem:
lemma
fixes doubles :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> bool"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x y. doubles x y = (x = y)"
and h1 : "\<forall> x y. x \<in> {1..6} \<and> y \<in> {1..6} \<longrightarrow> prob {(x, y). doubles x y} = 1 / 6"
shows  "prob {(x, y). doubles x y} = 1 / 6"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Two fair 6-sided dice are rolled.  What is the probability "doubles" are rolled (i.e., that the two dice show the same number)? The final Answer is \dfrac{1}{6}
 ### Proof
 There are 6 different ways to roll doubles which means the probability of rolling doubles is $\dfrac{6}{36} = \boxed{\dfrac{1}{6}}$.
 *)

lemma
fixes doubles :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> bool"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x y. doubles x y = (x = y)"
and h1 : "\<forall> x y. x \<in> {1..6} \<and> y \<in> {1..6} \<longrightarrow> prob {(x, y). doubles x y} = 1 / 6"
shows  "prob {(x, y). doubles x y} = 1 / 6"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: If we define a function "doubles" such that for any two numbers x and y, "doubles x y" is true if and only if x equals y. Now consider a pair of numbers (x,y) where both x and y are in the set {1,2,3,4,5,6}. What is the probability that "doubles x y" is true for a randomly selected pair (x,y)? The answer is 1/6.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes d1 d2 :: nat and P :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> d1 d2. d1 \<in> {1..6} \<and> d2 \<in> {1..6} \<longrightarrow> P d1 d2 = 1 / 36"
and h1 : "\<forall> d. d \<in> {1..6} \<longrightarrow> P d d = 1 / 6"
shows  "sum (\<lambda>d. P d d) {1..6} = 1 / 6"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Two fair 6-sided dice are rolled.  What is the probability "doubles" are rolled (i.e., that the two dice show the same number)? The final Answer is \dfrac{1}{6}
 ### Proof
 There are 6 different ways to roll doubles which means the probability of rolling doubles is $\dfrac{6}{36} = \boxed{\dfrac{1}{6}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes d1 d2 :: nat and P :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> d1 d2. d1 \<in> {1..6} \<and> d2 \<in> {1..6} \<longrightarrow> P d1 d2 = 1 / 36"
and h1 : "\<forall> d. d \<in> {1..6} \<longrightarrow> P d d = 1 / 6"
shows  "sum (\<lambda>d. P d d) {1..6} = 1 / 6"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: Assume that two six-sided dice are rolled. If the probability of any pair of numbers (d1, d2) appearing is 1/36, and the probability of rolling the same number on both dice (d = d1 = d2) is 1/6, then what is the total probability of rolling the same number on both dice when summed over all numbers from 1 to 6? The final answer is 1/6.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem 
fixes doubles :: real
assumes h0 : "doubles = 1/6"
shows  "doubles = (1/6)"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Two fair 6-sided dice are rolled.  What is the probability "doubles" are rolled (i.e., that the two dice show the same number)? The final Answer is \dfrac{1}{6}
 ### Proof
 There are 6 different ways to roll doubles which means the probability of rolling doubles is $\dfrac{6}{36} = \boxed{\dfrac{1}{6}}$.
 *)

theorem 
fixes doubles :: real
assumes h0 : "doubles = 1/6"
shows  "doubles = (1/6)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: "Verify that the value of 'doubles' is equal to one-sixth."

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A B :: "nat set" and P :: "nat set \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "finite A"
and h1 : "finite B"
and h2 : "A = {1,2,3,4,5,6}"
and h3 : "B = {1,2,3,4,5,6}"
and h4 : "\<forall> x \<in> A. P {x} = 1 / 6"
and h5 : "\<forall> y \<in> B. P {y} = 1 / 6"
and h6 : "indep_events (\<lambda>i. {i}) (\<lambda>i. A)"
and h7 : "indep_events (\<lambda>i. {i}) (\<lambda>i. B)"
shows  "P {x \<in> A. P {x} = P {y \<in> B}} = 1 / 6"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Two fair 6-sided dice are rolled.  What is the probability "doubles" are rolled (i.e., that the two dice show the same number)? The final Answer is \dfrac{1}{6}
 ### Proof
 There are 6 different ways to roll doubles which means the probability of rolling doubles is $\dfrac{6}{36} = \boxed{\dfrac{1}{6}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes A B :: "nat set" and P :: "nat set \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "finite A"
and h1 : "finite B"
and h2 : "A = {1,2,3,4,5,6}"
and h3 : "B = {1,2,3,4,5,6}"
and h4 : "\<forall> x \<in> A. P {x} = 1 / 6"
and h5 : "\<forall> y \<in> B. P {y} = 1 / 6"
and h6 : "indep_events (\<lambda>i. {i}) (\<lambda>i. A)"
and h7 : "indep_events (\<lambda>i. {i}) (\<lambda>i. B)"
shows  "P {x \<in> A. P {x} = P {y \<in> B}} = 1 / 6"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: Consider two finite sets A and B, each containing the numbers 1 through 6. Assign a probability of 1/6 to each element in both sets. If events in A and events in B are independent, find the probability that an element drawn from A has the same assigned probability as an element drawn from B. The final answer is 1/6.
